The world outside not yet loud.

Sunlight fingers through the glass,
Warming shadows on the floor.
I linger in this quiet space,
Hearing dreams behind the door.

The present hovers, feather-light,
Balancing between then and soon.
My thoughts, like birds, take hesitant flight,
Circling the edge of noon.

That's my window. This minute—
A frame for all I feel,
A silent pledge to hold the now,
Before the day turns real.

That's my window. This minute—
The hush of dawn pressed to the glass,
A glimpse of sky, a drifting thought,
Moments I wish would never pass.

The world outside is waking slow,
A train bell echoes down the street.
I watch, a silent observer,
As night and morning gently meet.

A curtain stirs, the light grows bold,
Yet here I linger, safe and still,
Cradled in the gentle hold
Of time that bends to will.

That's my window. This minute—
A brief and golden stay,
Where I can breathe, and just exist,
Before I face the day.

That's my window. This minute—
A slice of sky, uncertain blue,
The gentle hush before the rush,
A world waiting to renew.

I press my palm against the glass,
Feel the cool and silent pane,
Outside, the city stirs at last,
Inside, I remain.

Sunlight spills in golden streaks,
A bird sings on the wire,
My mind drifts in the quiet peaks
Of hope and small desire.

That's my window. This minute—
A pause, a fleeting view,
A moment held in trembling light,
Before the day breaks through.

That's my window. This minute—
Soft gold slipping past the blinds,
The city’s hush in early light,
A thousand silent, waking minds.

I watch the morning paint the street,
Each shadow stretching, thin and long.
I linger in the quiet seat,
Where minutes drift like gentle song.

A bird flits by, a car rolls slow,
The world renews its hopeful spin.
I breathe the hush, I let it flow,
And gather peace before I begin.

That's my window. This minute—
A threshold, small and bright.
I hold the day, not yet in it,
Safe behind this fragile light.

That's my window. This minute—
A square of possibility, trembling bright,
Where morning leans across the sill,
And quiet dreams take flight.

The city’s hush, a distant hum,
Softens edges, blurs the day.
I rest within this gentle space,
Letting time slip quietly away.

A bird’s shadow dances on the wall,
Sunlight pools on the floor.
I watch, content, as moments fall—
Each one richer than before.

That's my window. This minute—
A silent promise, pure and new.
A world just waking up to see
What wonder now will do.

That's my window. This minute—
A frame of trembling, golden light,
Where morning spills its gentle hush,
And dreams dissolve in flight.

The city stirs in distant waves,
A pigeon coos upon the sill.
Here, in the hush of waking day,
Time waits, and all is still.

I press my hand against the glass,
Feel the coolness, watch the rain.
In this small slice of everything,
I gather loss and gain.

That's my window. This minute—
A threshold, brief and bright,
A moment I can call my own,
Before I join the light.

That's my window. This minute—
A patch of sky, a fleeting cloud,
The hush before the world awakes,
The city not yet loud.

I watch the day stretch out its hand,
A promise painted blue and gold.
In this small space, I understand
How minutes slip and moments hold.

A bird calls out, the morning stirs,
A neighbor’s laughter down the lane.
I linger here, where silence blurs
The border between joy and pain.

That's my window. This minute—
A quiet frame for all I see,
A world in pause, a breath of now,
Belonging just to me.

That's my window. This minute—
A hush of gold upon the sill,
The city waking, slow and sweet,
The world outside is soft and still.

I watch the light crawl up the wall,
My breath a cloud upon the glass,
A moment’s peace before the call
Of time that soon will pass.

A bird’s song drifts across the street,
A car’s engine hums below,
In this small hour, life feels complete,
The day’s bright seeds in tow.

That's my window. This minute—
A precious pause, a gentle start,
A quiet corner of the world,
Held safely in my heart.

That's my window. This minute—
A trembling frame of waking light,
Where dreams dissolve and shadows fade
And hope arrives, feather-light.

The hush before the morning grows,
A sparrow’s song against the glass,
The golden hush that gently flows,
Insisting now is all that lasts.

I watch the world begin to move,
The city’s heart begins to beat,
But here, I linger, slow and true,
Held softly in my seat.

That's my window. This minute—
A threshold, small and bright,
A world suspended, infinite,
Before I step into the light.

That's my window. This minute—
A patch of sky, a drifting hue,
The city’s hush, a distant song,
The day not yet come through.

I linger at the fragile glass,
Watch morning’s gold unfurl,
A bird’s wing passes, swift and fast,
A memory in a whirl.

The world outside is waking slow,
A gentle, stretching yawn;
But here, I keep the silence close,
The softness of the dawn.

That's my window. This minute—
A frame for all I see,
A fleeting space of quietness,
That briefly shelters me.

That's my window. This minute—
Sunlight catching on the pane,
A world outside both close and far,
A hush that I can't name.

I press my palm against the glass,
Feel the coolness seep within.
A bird flits by, a whisper passed,
The day about to begin.

In this small, trembling interval,
Time pauses, soft and sweet.
The city stirs in distant thrall,
But here I find retreat.

That's my window. This minute—
A place where I belong,
A fleeting space, a gentle pause,
Before the day grows strong.

That's my window. This minute—
A trembling square of light,
Where morning tiptoes, gentle, pale,
And dreams recede from night.

I watch the world unfold beyond,
A city waking slow,
With distant cars and birds in song,
And sun’s first golden glow.

Inside, the silence gathers close,
A quiet, sacred space.
I hold the hush, I hold the hope
That daybreak can embrace.

That's my window. This minute—
A frame for all I feel,
A fleeting moment, shining bright,
Before the world turns real.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Where there is a need'

responses.text:
Where there is a need, a gentle hand appears,
A word, a glance, a balm for hidden fears.
In silent corners where the lonely dwell,
A spark is kindled, hope begins to swell.

Where there is a need, compassion softly grows,
Unfolding petals where the wild wind blows.
A stranger’s kindness, unexpected light,
Turns darkest hours into radiant night.

Where there is a need, our spirits intertwine,
Invisible threads, resilient by design.
For every burden shared, the world is less alone—
Where there is a need, love finds its home.

Where there is a need, a whisper calls,
Echoing softly through the marble halls
Of hearts that listen and eyes that see,
A world in want, a chance to be free.

Where there is a need, hands reach out,
Breaking through barriers, dispelling doubt.
Small acts of kindness, seeds gently sown,
Grow into forests from once-barren stone.

Where there is a need, hope takes flight,
Guided by compassion through the night.
We build together, strong and true,
Where there is a need, there is me and you.

Where there is a need, the world shifts its gaze,
Turning from comfort to uncertain maze.
A hand outstretched, a promise unspoken,
A kindness that mends what once was broken.

Where there is a need, the brave appear,
Bearing the burdens, swallowing fear.
Hope’s quiet anthem, a soft serenade,
Restores the weary, the lost, the afraid.

Where there is a need, new dreams take root,
In the soil of empathy, tender and mute.
And so, beneath sorrow, compassion proceeds—
A garden of solace where there is a need.

Where there is a need, a lantern glows bright,
Guiding the traveler lost in the night.
Silent and steady, a beacon of care,
Illuminating hearts with warmth to spare.

Where there is a need, courage takes form,
Sheltering souls from the gathering storm.
In the hush of despair, a promise is made—
To answer the call, unafraid, unafraid.

Where there is a need, humanity thrives,
Weaving together our disparate lives.
In giving, in loving, in word and in deed,
We answer the world where there is a need.

Where there is a need, silence breaks,
Into a thousand hopeful wakes.
A gentle touch, a caring face,
Arrives to fill an empty space.

Where there is a need, hearts respond,
With empathy that grows beyond.
A woven net of hands and dreams,
Stitching hope through broken seams.

Where there is a need, we find our voice,
To lift the fallen, to give them choice.
So let us listen, let us heed—
For love is sown where there is a need.

Where there is a need, I find a call,
Rising gentle, soft through the pall.
A child’s hunger, a lonely sigh,
Echoes beneath a sleepless sky.

Where there is a need, I search for grace,
In worn hands and weathered face.
A cup of water, a quiet word,
The smallest gestures, often unheard.

Where there is a need, I too belong,
In threads of kindness, woven strong.
For every heart that aches or bleeds—
We answer softly, where there is a need.

Where there is a need, the world unfolds,
From silent shadows, a story told.
A gentle presence, a whispered cheer,
A moment's comfort, drawing near.

Where there is a need, hope finds a way,
Lighting the corners of darkest day.
Hands open wide, hearts align,
Bridges are built, lives entwine.

Where there is a need, love takes its stand,
Binding the earth in a golden band.
So let us answer, in word and deed,
The quiet call, where there is a need.

Where there is a need, the river flows,
Carrying mercy where pain overflows.
Roots of compassion dig deep in the earth,
Nourishing dreams, encouraging birth.

Where there is a need, voices unite,
Turning the shadows toward the light.
A patchwork of kindness, sewn tight with care,
Blankets the weary, assures they’re aware.

Where there is a need, we are called to give,
To witness, to comfort, to help others live.
For in each gentle answer, a promise is freed—
The heart of the world, where there is a need.

Where there is a need, morning breaks anew,
With gentle rays that promise to pursue
The lonely, the weary, the silent, the small—
A beacon of hope that answers the call.

Where there is a need, footsteps fall in line,
Carrying burdens both yours and mine.
Through kindness and patience, through struggle and creed,
We build a tomorrow where hearts are freed.

Where there is a need, the world comes near,
In laughter, in sorrow, in every tear.
A tapestry woven by those who heed—
A promise fulfilled, where there is a need.

Where there is a need, a seed is sown,
In soil of longing, in fields unknown.
From roots of kindness, branches extend,
Offering shelter, inviting a friend.

Where there is a need, courage is found,
In voices that tremble, in hearts unbound.
The smallest gesture, the simplest deed,
Becomes the answer where there is a need.

Where there is a need, the world is changed,
Boundaries soften, the lines rearranged.
Let us be present, let us take heed—
We are the answer, where there is a need.

Where there is a need, the world bends low,
Soft as the rain, steady as snow.
A cup is filled, a wound is dressed,
A tired soul is gently blessed.

Where there is a need, the strong grow kind,
Leaving their certainties behind.
A whispered word, a heartfelt deed,
Answers the call, where there is a need.

Where there is a need, new hope is born,
In darkest night, in breaking morn.
We rise together, in thought and creed,
To fill the space where there is a need.

Where there is a need, the dawn arrives,
Unfurling light in shadowed lives.
A hand to steady, a voice to guide,
Comfort and courage walking beside.

Where there is a need, we gather near,
Easing sorrow, soothing fear.
A network of hearts, beating as one,
Until the healing work is done.

Where there is a need, let us be found,
Planting hope in broken ground.
For in every kindness, small as a seed,
We find our purpose where there is a need.

Where there is a need, I hear the song
Of voices yearning to belong.
A hush of sorrow, a silent plea,
Echoes through the world to me.

Where there is a need, I see the flame
Of hope that never burns the same.
In every gesture, in every deed,
Compassion answers, filling need.

Where there is a need, I’ll take my place,
With open arms and steady grace.
For every soul who aches or bleeds,
Let love be given where there is a need.

Where there is a need, hearts awaken,
From comfort’s slumber, softly shaken.
A gentle murmur, a yearning sigh,
A call for help drifting by.

Where there is a need, hands entwine,
Offering hope, a lifeline.
In kindness, a quiet seed is sown—
No one truly stands alone.

Where there is a need, love persists,
Through whispered prayers and clasped fists.
Let us answer, swift and heed,
The silent summons where there is a need.

Where there is a need, the world pauses,
Breathes in sorrow, breathes out causes.
A cup of water, a steady hand,
Promises made to help and stand.

Where there is a need, kindness grows,
In gentle acts that no one knows.
A blanket, a smile, a meal to share,
Compassion’s answer is always there.

Where there is a need, we come together,
No storm too great, no trial too weathered.
For in each giving, we plant a seed—
Love’s lasting harvest, where there is a need.

Where there is a need, the silence is loud,
Calling for kindness from out of the crowd.
A glance, a gesture, a word well-spoken,
Lifts up a spirit so nearly broken.

Where there is a need, let mercy rise,
Bridging the gaps with caring ties.
For every ache, a hand is found,
For every sorrow, hope abounds.

Where there is a need, we’re never apart,
Bound by the threads of the human heart.
So let us answer, let us heed—
The world’s quiet plea, where there is a need.

Where there is a need, the story begins,
In quiet corners, in secret sins.
A longing for comfort, a search for a friend,
A hope for the ache and hunger to end.

Where there is a need, the brave draw near,
With gentle words to calm the fear.
In darkness, in doubt, in times of despair,
A hand is offered, someone cares.

Where there is a need, the answer is found,
In every heart that hears the sound.
Let us be present, let us proceed—
To shine a light where there is a need.

Where there is a need, hearts beat strong,
Finding right in what feels wrong.
A silent wish, a silent prayer,
Met by someone willing to care.

Where there is a need, we turn to face
The challenge, the sorrow, the empty space.
A gentle word, a helping hand,
Builds a bridge across the land.

Where there is a need, hope endures,
Kindness given, pain ensures.
Let us be willing, let us take heed—
To answer gently where there is a need.

Where there is a need, the world awaits,
With open doors and unlocked gates.
A touch, a smile, a listening ear,
Dispersing shadows, erasing fear.

Where there is a need, love is sown,
In every act of grace we’ve known.
A circle of giving, a chain of care,
Binding us all, everywhere.

Where there is a need, let us be near,
Bringing solace, quelling fear.
For every plea, let hearts accede—
To answer softly where there is a need.

Where there is a need, the light extends,
Softly, gently, the darkness bends.
A single action, a spoken word,
May be the hope someone has not heard.

Where there is a need, we draw near,
Bringing comfort, easing fear.
Through tangled paths and stormy skies,
Compassion lifts, and sorrow flies.

Where there is a need, let us not turn,
From pain or hunger, from ache or yearn.
For in our giving, we are freed—
And love is sown where there is a need.

Where there is a need, a spark ignites,
Piercing the hush of the loneliest nights.
A gentle gesture, a smile so true,
Can carry a soul, can see them through.

Where there is a need, let hearts convene,
Where empathy dwells, where hope is seen.
We gather together, side by side,
In the warmth of kindness, let us abide.

Where there is a need, we all belong,
A tapestry woven, resilient and strong.
Let every answer, every good deed,
Be the promise kept where there is a need.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Let the night sleep'

responses.text:
Let the night sleep, hush now the stars,
Blanket the world with silence, near and far.
Let dreams drift gently, soft and deep,
In the cradle of darkness, let the night sleep.

Moonbeams tiptoe across the floor,
Whispering secrets from the closed door.
Clouds pull curtains over the sky,
While shadows yawn, and lullabies sigh.

Let the worries of daylight quietly fade,
As silver threads of rest are laid.
Let every creature, great and small,
Find peace in the hush that covers all.

Let the night sleep, the world at rest,
Hearts beating calm within each chest.
'Til dawn awakens with golden sweep,
Cherish the hush, and let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, let it rest its weary head,
Tuck the darkness in, smooth the silver spread.
The crickets hum their lullaby, the owls begin to weep,
While dreams drift softly in, let the night sleep.

Clouds cradle the moon, gentle and deep,
Stars blink slowly, sinking into the sweep
Of shadow and silence, as old as time,
A hush falls over every tree and line.

Let troubles unravel, let worries release,
In the hush of the night, find your peace.
Tomorrow will come with its work and its heat—
But for now, let the night sleep, gentle and sweet.

Let the night sleep, do not disturb her peace,
Tread lightly as moonbeams, let her quiet increase.
The stars are her guardians, the clouds her quilt,
Soft silence the language in which her dreams are built.

Let the city’s hum hush, let the wild winds cease,
Let the creatures of darkness find gentle release.
As the world turns inward, and time softly creeps,
Let the night sleep—while the universe keeps.

Let the night sleep, let silence reign,
No footsteps echo, no whisper of pain.
The world wrapped softly in indigo sheets,
A lullaby sung where day and night meet.

Let the wind hush its longing, the stars close their eyes,
Let moonlight grow gentle, let darkness baptize.
In this deep slumber, let worries retreat,
Let the night sleep, whole and complete.

Let the night sleep, hush its gentle sigh,
Blanket the world in velvet sky.
Let worries fade like distant light,
Rest in the cradle of silent night.

Let the moon guard with silver gaze,
While dreams drift in a silent haze.
Give quiet sanctuary to every heart,
As shadows and starlight softly part.

Let the night sleep, let it be still,
The world at peace, hearts calm and will.
Until the dawn’s first gentle sweep,
Hold the darkness close—let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, let her dreams unfold,
Her secrets shimmering, silver and cold.
Beneath quiet stars and the moon’s soft sweep,
Let the world hush now, let the night sleep.

Let the wind rest its wings, the shadows lie low,
Let silence blossom where wild thoughts grow.
May every worry drift away, deep,
Cradled in darkness—let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, let the world exhale,
Close every window, draw every veil.
The gentle hush of darkness creeps,
Over fields and rivers, while the city sleeps.

Let the stars whisper their ancient tale,
Let the moonlight shimmer, pale and frail.
Hold your breath and listen deep—
To the quiet song: let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, fold it gently away,
Wrap the darkness in velvet, let dreams have their say.
Let the hush settle over rooftops and trees,
And rest ride quietly on a cool midnight breeze.

Let the clocks slow their ticking, the world’s worries cease,
Let hearts settle softly in silvery peace.
Under the watch of the stars, so distant and deep,
Let the night slumber sweetly—let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, undisturbed and deep,
Covering the world in a velvet sweep.
Let the stars dim their watchful gaze,
And the moon retreat in a gentle haze.

Hush the city, the fields, the stream,
Let them sink softly into a dream.
For in this quiet, all worries release,
Let the night sleep, let the world find peace.

Let the night sleep, let shadows rest,
Fold the silence close to your chest.
Let the stars be still, the moon hang low,
Let the world forget what it cannot know.

Let the hush carry you, soft and deep,
Where memories drift and old wounds sleep.
In the velvet cradle where darkness keeps,
Let the night sleep, while the dreamer weeps.

Let the night sleep, let the hush descend,
Let the gentle darkness quietly mend.
Let the stars blink softly in the sky,
And the crescent moon silently pass by.

Let the worries of day drift far away,
Let the midnight breeze in silence sway.
As the world grows still, and shadows creep,
Let the night sleep, let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, in velvet embrace,
Stars blink softly in infinite space.
Moonlight weaves silence through window and street,
Cradling the world in gentle retreat.

Let the hush deepen, let dreams softly creep,
Over the cities, the forests, the deep.
Until morning stirs in a golden sweep,
Hold close the darkness—let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, close its heavy eyes,
Let the moon’s lullaby silence the cries.
The city’s heart beats slower now,
Stars gather gently upon night’s brow.

Let silence settle in corners deep,
Let the world drift softly, let the night sleep.
Dreams will wander and shadows keep,
A promise of peace—let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, let it lie undisturbed,
Silent as feathers, each worry uncurbed.
Let the dark be gentle, the shadows kind,
A soft, cool pillow for every mind.

Let the clocks slow down, let the world unwind,
Let moon and stars their watch assign.
Rest in the stillness, let dreams sweep,
Over your soul—let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, let worries fade,
Beneath the hush that darkness made.
The world grows quiet, slow and deep,
In gentle arms, let the night sleep.

Let the moon drift behind a veil,
Let dreams carry on the midnight gale.
Softly, gently, shadows creep,
Blanketing earth—let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, let the world be still,
Beneath the hush of the midnight chill.
Let the stars blink softly in the sky,
As the hours in silence drift by.

Let the troubles of day slip away,
Folded in darkness until the next day.
In the quiet, where dreams softly sweep,
Let hearts find rest—let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, let it cradle the world,
As moonbeams and starlight gently unfurl.
Let the cool breeze carry away the day,
And let quiet shadows silently play.

Let the night sleep, give it your trust,
Let it blanket your worries in shimmering dust.
Rest in the silence, soft and deep,
Let the world breathe out—let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, draw the curtains tight,
Let silver shadows dance out of sight.
Let every worry, every sigh,
Slip away quietly as hours pass by.

Let the hush settle over the land,
Dreams drifting gently, hand in hand.
Until the dawn’s first promise peeps,
Let the world be still—let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, let darkness be kind,
Let peace and quiet blanket the mind.
Let the stars dim their shimmering light,
And the world dissolve into gentle night.

Let the hush deepen, let silence keep,
All wandering thoughts and secrets we reap.
For in the velvet, in shadows so deep,
Let all things rest—let the night sleep.

Let the night sleep, hush the restless wind,
Let the silent hours softly begin.
The moon whispers comfort, shadows embrace,
As the world finds its gentle, dreaming place.

Let cares unravel, let time slow its sweep,
Cradled in darkness, let the night sleep.
Until dawn’s fingers reach over the deep,
Let the hush linger—let the night sleep.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

responses.text:
People wish to be settled, to plant roots in gentle ground,  
To find comfort in the silence, in familiar sights and sound.  
But it is the wind that stirs the branches, the storm that shapes the sea,  
The restless urge to wander, that sets the spirit free.  
Hope is born in motion, in the longing and the quest,  
In the ache of destination just beyond each hopeful step.  
Settled hearts may slumber, but the wakeful soul will roam—  
For it’s only in unsettlement that hope becomes our home.

They long for peace, a quiet shore,  
A place to lay their burdens down.  
Yet in the restless undertow,  
Hope’s shining seeds are sown.  
For comfort breeds a gentle sleep,  
And dreams can fade to gray,  
But in the shifting, searching dark,  
New dawns are born each day.  
Let hearts be stirred by winds unknown,  
Let questions light the night—  
For only in the unsettled soul  
Does hope burn ever bright.

People long for settled lives,  
For certainty and rest;  
Yet hope is born on shifting tides,  
In dreams that leave the nest.  
When comfort dulls ambition’s spark,  
And peace becomes a cage,  
The soul grows silent, dim, and dark,  
Contentment turns to age.  
But let the heart be restless still,  
Let longing fan the flame—  
For only those who climb the hill  
Find hope to stake their claim.

We yearn for calm, for settled ground,  
A hearth, a home, a certainty—  
Yet in our hearts, a whisper’s found,  
A hunger for what’s yet to be.  
Hope flickers in unsettled dreams,  
In questions, doubts, and open doors;  
The river’s course is never still—  
It carves new paths upon its shores.  
So let us cherish all unrest,  
The ache for more, the urge to roam;  
For only those unsettled yet  
Can ever truly hope for home.

We wish for settled days and nights,  
A comfort in the known;  
But hope is born in shifting lights,  
Where seeds of doubt are sown.  
For certainty can close the door,  
And lull the soul to sleep,  
While restlessness creates a shore  
Where dreams and wishes leap.  
Let not the longing ever fade,  
Nor quiet all your fears—  
For only when unsettled made  
Can hope appear through tears.

To be settled—oh, the dream!  
A life of calm, a gentle stream.  
Yet in that stillness, hope lies low,  
A spark unlit, a seed that won’t grow.  
It’s in the trembling, restless night,  
In hearts that yearn for distant light,  
That hope’s bright fire finds its air—  
In all we seek, in all we dare.  
Let the journey never cease,  
Let longing offer no release;  
For only in the unquiet soul  
Does hope arise to make us whole.

They wish for settled earth beneath their feet,  
A place where worries fall away and rest feels sweet.  
But hope is a bird unsettled, wings half-spread,  
That calls you onward, restless, to roads ahead.  
Contentment lulls the dream, but longing fans the spark,  
The heart must ache with questions, must wander in the dark.  
So bless the wind that lifts you, the tide that pulls you far,  
For hope is born in motion, and guides us like a star.

People wish to be settled, to find rest from the storm,  
To fold their hands in quiet, to warm themselves in form.  
But hope is a wild current, a river running deep,  
It thrives when we are searching, not lulled into sleep.  
Let the heart remain unsettled, let the longing never cease,  
For in the dance of yearning, the soul will find release.  
Hope is not in endings, but in beginnings yet unknown;  
In the ache to keep on seeking, we find ourselves grown.

People yearn for certainty, a hearth, a place to stay,  
A gentle hush of answers to keep the dark at bay.  
Yet hope is found in movement, in questions left unasked,  
In restless dreams that wander far from every settled task.  
Let not the longing cease, nor comfort dull the mind;  
For in the trembling, open space, new light is what we find.  
So bless the tides that stir the soul and winds that make us roam—  
For hope is ever brightest when we’re far away from home.

We crave the calm, the steady ground,  
A place where fears grow small;  
Yet hope is born in restless sound,  
In longing’s distant call.  
The heart must ache to understand,  
To search and never rest;  
For only when we leave the sand  
Do we pursue our best.  
Let peace come not from settling down,  
But from the journey’s sweep—  
For hope is found in paths unknown,  
And in the dreams we keep.

People wish for stillness, for a life of peaceful ease,  
But hope is in the trembling, in the shaking of the trees.  
We seek the gentle harbor, the comfort of the known,  
Yet hope is in the journey, in the seeds that we have sown.  
Let not the heart grow silent nor the longing ever cease,  
For in the unrest of living, the soul will find its peace.  
To be unsettled is to hope, to wander and to yearn—  
For only in the seeking can the world begin to turn.

We yearn for peace, a place to rest—  
A home where dreams grow old;  
Yet hope is found in wild unrest,  
In hearts that can’t be told.  
For when we settle, longing fades,  
Desire slips away;  
But in the night that never stays,  
Hope wakes to greet the day.  
Let us not hush the hungry soul,  
Nor quiet all our fears—  
For only when unsettled whole  
Does hope shine through the years.

We yearn to be settled, to finish the quest,  
To sleep in the harbor and dream of our rest.  
Yet hope is a traveler with dust on its feet,  
It lives in the journey, in longing’s heartbeat.  
For comfort is gentle, but restless the mind  
That seeks out the promise the future will find.  
So let us stay searching, our spirits not still—  
For hope is unsettled, and always will.

People wish to be settled, to anchor their hearts in the known,  
But hope is the wind in the branches, the longing that calls us alone.  
A life that is certain and quiet may soothe us for only a while,  
Yet hope is a restless companion, it lives in the risk and the trial.  
So may we not settle too quickly, nor silence the questions we bear,  
For only in being unsettled can hope draw us out of despair.  
Let us welcome the stirrings of longing, the ache that will not be stilled—  
For hope is the song of the seeker, a dream that cannot be filled.

We long for settled waters, for a shore where we belong,  
Yet hope is in the distance, in the call of siren song.  
To be at rest is lovely, but the heart must sometimes roam,  
For only in the wandering does hope become our home.  
Let us cherish all uncertainty, the questions and the quest,  
For hope is found in seeking, in the journey not at rest.  
People wish to be settled, but hope is restless air—  
It’s only when unsettled that hope is truly there.

People wish to be settled, to find peace in what they know,  
But hope is restless longing, the urge to learn and grow.  
In comfort, dreams can wither; in certainty, hearts sleep—  
Yet hope stirs in confusion, in promises we keep.  
Let us welcome the unanswered, the doubts that never rest,  
For only in unsettlement can hope become our guest.  
So, may we roam and wonder, let questions lead the way—  
For hope is found in seeking what tomorrow dares to say.

People wish for settled lives, for peace to call their own,  
But hope is not a gentle stream, it’s wild and overgrown.  
Contentment breeds a silent dusk, a stillness far from light,  
Yet hope is born in restless dusk and dreams that wake the night.  
So let us not be settled, but let longing guide our way—  
For hope is found in seeking, in the breaking of the day.  
It’s only in our wandering, our hearts not yet at rest,  
That hope will live within us and call us to our best.

We wish to be settled, to find answers and peace,  
But hope is a question that never will cease.  
In comfort we slumber, in certainty fade,  
Yet hope is the hunger for paths not yet made.  
Let us cherish the stirring, the ache to explore—  
For only unsettled do we long for more.  
Hope lives in the searching, in restless delight,  
A fire in the darkness, a song in the night.

People wish to be settled, to find solace in the known,  
But hope is in the restless heart, in seeds not yet sown.  
A settled mind may find its peace, but dreams will wither slow,  
For hope is in the shifting tides, the urge to learn and grow.  
Let us not be too content, nor silence every doubt,  
For only in unsettlement can hope come reaching out.  
Embrace the unknown journey, let longing lead the way—  
For hope is ever waiting in the dawn of each new day.

They wish for settlement, a home where time stands still,  
Yet hope is in the yearning, the quest for something still.  
In the comfort of the known, the heart may fall asleep,  
But in the wild uncertainty, hope rises from the deep.  
Let us not fear the longing, nor mourn the restless soul—  
For hope is found in striving, in dreams that make us whole.  
May we remain unsettled, with questions in our eyes—  
For hope is ever brightest where the unknown horizon lies.

People wish for peace, a place to lay their head,  
But hope is in the wandering, in the roads still left to tread.  
To settle is to quiet dreams, to anchor in the sand,  
Yet hope is in the trembling heart, the open, outstretched hand.  
So let us keep unsettled, let longing be our guide—  
For hope is in the journey, not the end where we reside.  
The restless soul is hopeful, the seeking heart is brave,  
And only in unsettlement can hope begin to save.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I walk alone, I think of you my love'

responses.text:
When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Each step a soft echo in twilight’s hush,
Your memory drifts beneath the silent grove,
As gentle winds through autumn branches brush.

Your laughter lingers in the amber air,
A melody that guides my wandering feet,
I trace your shadow, though you’re never there,
Yet in my heart, we always seem to meet.

Night’s velvet cloak wraps close around my frame,
But warms me less than thoughts of you can do,
Stars blink above and whisper out your name,
Their silver glances shimmering with dew.

When I walk alone, I carry you inside—
My love, my solace, my secret, my guide.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
With each footfall, your memory is near.
The silence of the evening sky above
Wraps me in longing, quiet and clear.

Shadows stretch, gentle on the street,
I hear your laughter in the whispering leaves.
Every empty bench, every corner I meet,
Holds a story that my heart believes.

The night air cools, but I feel your heat,
A warmth within me, soft and true.
Alone, but never incomplete—
For every path I walk, I walk with you.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Your memory floats on the evening breeze,
Under the watchful eyes of stars above,
My heart finds solace and gentle ease.

Every silent step recalls your touch,
Every shadow hints at your face,
In the hush of night, I miss you much,
Yet in this solitude, I find your grace.

The world grows quiet, the city sleeps,
But my thoughts of you remain awake,
In the darkness, where longing seeps,
I cherish the love we never forsake.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The world around me silent, save my mind,
Where whispers of your presence softly shove
Away the emptiness I always find.

The moon above me glows with borrowed light,
A gentle guide as shadows stretch and bend,
And in the cool embrace of coming night,
I hold your memory—my constant friend.

Though distance lies between us, undefined,
My every step draws closer to your heart.
When I walk alone, you’re with me in my mind,
Together still, though we may be apart.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
With every step upon the quiet ground,
Your voice drifts down from distant stars above,
A melody in silence all around.

The gentle breeze recalls the way you smiled,
And every leaf, a whisper of your name.
Though miles may stretch, and seasons may be wild,
Within my heart, our love remains the same.

I wander through the dusk in reverie,
The world grows soft, the evening shadows blend.
Yet in my solitude, you walk with me—
A silent presence that will never end.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The golden dusk falls softly on my face.
I hear your laughter in the mourning dove,
And in each shadow, your familiar grace.

My footsteps echo down the empty street,
A rhythm that recalls your gentle ways.
Memories and wishes often meet,
Woven in the hush of closing days.

Though distance lies between our outstretched hands,
And time divides the paths we choose to roam,
I feel your heart in every grain of sand,
And in this quiet, I am not alone.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Each footstep draws your image in my mind.
The world grows quiet, stars appear above,
And in the hush, your memory I find.

The streetlights flicker shadows on the ground,
Reminding me of laughter we once shared.
In solitude, your absence wraps me round,
Yet comfort comes in knowing that you cared.

Though miles may lie between your heart and mine,
The thought of you brings warmth against the chill.
As evening falls and constellations shine,
My love for you is present, constant, still.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Beneath the quiet hush of fading day.
Each passing cloud, each star that shines above,
Reminds me of the words we used to say.

The world is painted in a twilight hue,
My heart recalls the touch of your embrace.
With every step, my thoughts return to you,
And find your presence in this empty space.

Though solitude may walk beside me now,
And distance keeps our hands apart,
I hold our memories, silent and proud,
And carry you always in my heart.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Your memory a gentle shadow near.
The quiet lanes, the silver sky above,
Are colored bright by thoughts of you, my dear.

Each footstep falls in rhythm with your name,
Each breeze recalls the softness of your touch.
Though night descends and all the world is tame,
Within my soul, I feel you just as much.

The world may turn and seasons come and go,
But in the hush, your spirit stays with me.
When I walk alone, it’s you I always know—
My heart’s companion for eternity.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
My footsteps echo in the evening air.
A gentle longing settles from above,
And memories of you are everywhere.

I see your smile in moonlit window panes,
I hear your laughter in the rustling trees.
Your absence lingers softly in my veins,
A bittersweet companion on the breeze.

Though solitude may press against my chest,
I find your presence warming through the cold.
For love like ours survives the hardest test—
When I walk alone, your hand I still hold.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The city’s hush, a canvas for my heart.
My thoughts drift upward to the stars above,
Where dreams of you and I will never part.

The gentle wind recalls your whispered name,
It weaves your laughter through the open air.
Each memory, a softly glowing flame,
Reminds me that your spirit lingers there.

Though miles may stretch between us far and wide,
Your presence walks beside me in the night.
In every shadow, I feel you reside,
My constant love, my comfort, and my light.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The world grows silent in the fading light.
Your memory, like a feather from above,
Drifts down and makes the lonely evening bright.

I count the steps that lead me down the lane,
Each one a wish that you were by my side.
In twilight’s hush, I whisper your sweet name,
And feel you near though distance may divide.

The stars appear, companions in the dark,
Their silver glow a promise shining true.
When I walk alone, I carry in my heart
The hope that someday I’ll return to you.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The gentle rhythm of my steps recalls
The laughter that we shared, the dreams thereof,
The moments etched in memory’s quiet halls.

The evening air is scented with your grace,
A whisper of your hand within my own.
I seek your shadow in the empty space,
And find my heart is never quite alone.

Though distance stretches far between our days,
And silence grows where once your voice would be,
My love endures in countless subtle ways—
You walk beside me in my reverie.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
With every echo of my measured pace.
The moonlit path, the silent sky above,
Reminds me of your gentle, smiling face.

My thoughts retrace the journeys that we shared,
The laughter that would linger in the air.
Now solitude is something I have dared,
For in my heart, I know that you are there.

Each night, the stars bear witness to my vow,
To hold you close, no matter where you are.
When I walk alone, I think of you, and how
Your love still guides me, shining from afar.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The hush of night enfolds me as I roam.
Your memory drifts softly from above,
A distant star that guides my path toward home.

With every step, the shadows stretch and bend,
Yet in the quiet, I can hear your voice.
Though loneliness and longing never end,
Your laughter turns my sorrow into choice.

I walk beneath the sky’s embracing blue,
And wonder if you think of me as well.
When I walk alone, I carry you—
A whispered promise only time will tell.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The world a quiet hush, the evening deep.
I see your smile reflected from above,
In every star that guards me as I sleep.

Your laughter lingers softly on the air,
A phantom touch that follows where I stray.
Though shadows fall and solitude is there,
Your memory lights gently on my way.

Each step I take is guided by your song,
A melody that only I can hear.
When I walk alone, it’s you all along,
My love, my hope, my ever-present dear.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Each footfall sings a quiet, longing tune.
The dusk wraps me in memories thereof,
And dreams of you are sheltered by the moon.

The world is vast, the city lights grow dim,
Yet in my heart, your laughter softly stays.
I wander onward, edges blurred and slim,
Carrying your light through winding ways.

Though solitude may press upon my chest,
Your gentle presence never truly fades.
When I walk alone, I know I’m blessed—
For love like ours, no distance ever shades.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The gentle rhythm of my steps recalls
Your laughter echoing from far above,
And memories that linger in these halls.

The moonlight bathes the empty streets in grace,
A silver promise shining through the night.
Though distance keeps me from your warm embrace,
Your spirit walks beside me, soft and light.

In solitude, I find you ever near,
A whisper carried on the midnight air.
When I walk alone, I hold you dear—
My heart and soul are always with you there.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Each quiet step a memory reborn.
The gentle sky, the silent stars above,
Remind me of the day when we were sworn.

Your laughter drifts upon the evening breeze,
Your shadow slips beside me as I roam.
Though miles divide and time may never ease,
In solitude, I always find my home.

I carry you in every breath I take,
Your kindness lingers in the fading light.
When I walk alone, my heart will never break—
For loving you has made my spirit bright.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
With every breath, your memory appears.
The gentle hush of twilight falls above,
And in the dusk, I walk with all my fears.

But you, my dear, are comfort in the shade,
A distant whisper floating through the night.
Though loneliness and longing never fade,
Your presence fills the shadows with your light.

The world may seem a little colder now,
Yet hope endures in every dream we knew.
When I walk alone, I make this solemn vow:
To always keep my heart in love with you.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
A single figure on a winding road.
Your gentle voice descends from stars above,
And lightens every burden, every load.

I hear your laughter in the whispering air,
Your footsteps echo softly in my mind.
Though solitude may press me with its care,
The thought of you is solace, sweet and kind.

The world may darken, and the nights grow long,
But memories of you remain so bright.
When I walk alone, I carry on,
For loving you brings comfort to the night.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The path ahead is quiet, calm, and clear.
Your memory floats softly from above,
A gentle whisper only I can hear.

I see your smile in every passing face,
And feel your warmth in every summer breeze.
Though time and space may keep us from embrace,
My longing for you never seems to cease.

So as I wander through the empty street,
I hold you close within my hopeful heart.
When I walk alone, our souls still meet—
For love, though distant, never will depart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
With hands like bark and hearts grown tough,
Of furrowed brows and laughter loud,
Their feet planted firm, their heads unbowed.
Amidst the peat and autumn mist,
They raised their cups and shook their fists,
Yet in their eyes, a spark would gleam,
A gentler thought, a distant dream.
For though their voices roared like rain,
And songs spilled out like untamed grain,
Within each chest a longing burned,
A poet’s fire, a lesson learned.
He spoke of Burns and saw anew
The strength in those who plow and hew;
Their rough-hewn words, their honest verse,
A country’s soul, both gift and curse.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
With whisky breath and voices gruff,
Who tramped the heather, braved the storm,
Their laughter loud, their welcome warm.
They wore their hardships like a plaid,
No finer cloth was ever made.
Yet, in their songs and in their tears,
A gentler music pierced the years.
In humble bothy, field, or glen,
The poet’s words could soften men;
A simple verse, a heartfelt plea,
Could stir their souls, set spirits free.
So raise a glass to Burns’s name,
For in his lines, they’re all the same:
The rude, the rough, the kind, the true—
The heart of Scotland shining through.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Whose laughter echoed, wild and tough,
Who tilled the stubborn, stony ground,
And found in hardship joy profound.
The wind would whip their tartan plaids,
Their voices rose above the glades;
Yet in the tavern’s smoky haze,
They’d praise the poet’s honest ways.
For Burns saw beauty in their toil,
In muddy boots and honest soil,
In rugged hands and weathered skin,
A hidden tenderness within.
He spoke of Burns, of men like these,
Who loved the land, the wind, the trees,
Their simple lives, their hearts so wide,
With poetry they could not hide.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their laughter coarse, their hands calloused and tough.
With muddy boots and weathered faces,
They gathered in the fire-lit places.
Yet when the whiskey warmed their veins,
And winter battered windowpanes,
A softer voice would fill the air,
A verse of love, a whispered prayer.
For though their world was harsh and cold,
And stories often brashly told,
Within each heart a longing burned,
For beauty, truth, and hope returned.
He spoke of Burns, of common men,
Who found in words their strength again;
The poet’s fire, the peasant’s song—
Together, where they both belong.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
With calloused hands and spirits tough,
Yet in their eyes a twinkling spark,
A poet's fire against the dark.
They raised their mugs with hearty cheer,
Their laughter bold, their language clear,
But in the quiet, drifting smoke,
A gentler word they sometimes spoke.
For Burns, he knew their secret pain,
Their longing for the sun and rain,
He wrote of love, of loss, of pride,
The dreams that strong men never hide.
He spoke of Burns, and as he told
Of rugged men with hearts of gold,
We saw the poet in us all—
The hope that rises when we fall.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their cheeks wind-bitten, voices gruff,
Yet in their hearts, a poet’s tune,
Soft as the rising summer moon.
They ploughed the earth with hardened hands,
And tilled the dreams that shaped the lands.
But round the hearth, their tales would blend
With Burns’s words, as friend to friend.
For in their toil, his verses dwelled,
And in their laughter, longing swelled.
The roughest bark can hide the green,
And gentler souls in men unseen.
He spoke of Burns, and we could see
In every man, his poetry.
A nation’s strength, a humble pride,
With Burns’s song, they did not hide.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Who knew the earth, the wind, the bluff.
With weathered hands and stubborn pride,
They faced the storm, the rolling tide.
Yet in the flicker of the fire,
A softer longing would inspire.
For underneath the hardened skin,
A gentle heart would beat within.
Burns found the beauty in their toil,
Their laughter, love, the honest soil.
He wrote of lass and lad and land,
Of dreams that slip just like the sand.
So when he spoke of men so tough,
He saw the gold beneath the rough.
And in his words, both fierce and free,
He showed us all what men could be.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their laughter brash, their language tough.
They tilled the land, they braved the night,
They held their ground, they fought the fight.
Yet in their songs and in their tales,
The gentlest of the heart prevails.
For through the storm, through toil and strife,
They found the poet’s gift of life.
A glass was raised, a cheer was sung,
And ancient Scottish words were flung.
The bard’s own verses, proud and true,
Were kindled in the hearts they knew.
He spoke of Burns, and there we saw
The men who lived by nature’s law,
In every line, in every rhyme,
A soul enduring through all time.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their laughter coarse, their language gruff.
They bore the scars of wind and rain,
Yet sang of love and felt its pain.
With muddy boots and battered pride,
They toasted life, and none would hide
The softer ache beneath the jest,
A longing buried in each chest.
For Burns had seen beyond the skin,
The dreams and doubts that dwell within.
He wrote for those who till and sow,
Who fight the storm, who reap and mow.
He spoke of Burns, and in his voice,
The rude and rough would still rejoice,
To find a place within the song,
Where hearts both weak and strong belong.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
With laughter loud and hands so tough.
They raised their tankards, sang their tunes,
Beneath the wide and wistful moons.
Yet in their eyes a longing lay,
For something gentle, far away.
Though life was hard and nights were long,
They found their solace in a song.
For Burns had penned their secret dreams,
Their hopes, their fears, their silent screams.
He gave their world a poet’s voice,
And made the simple hearts rejoice.
So when he spoke, we understood
That even men of stone and wood
Could feel the beauty in a line,
And for a moment, be divine.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their laughter wild, their living tough,
Yet in the clatter of the night,
A spark of kindness, fleeting light.
With every cup, a tale was spun
Of battles lost and friendships won.
Though coarse of word and quick to jest,
The poet’s verses stirred their breast.
For Burns had seen their hidden grace,
The love that time could not erase.
He sang the truth of common men,
And lifted hope again, again.
He spoke of Burns, and in the sound,
The soul of Scotland’s heart was found;
A song for those who work and strive,
Who keep the common dream alive.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their laughter sharp, their manner gruff.
Yet under all, a gentle tune,
A longing for a summer’s June.
With every pint and every song,
They told of right, they told of wrong.
Burns found the beauty in the plain,
The joy in hardship, hope in pain.
In smoky rooms, by firelight’s glow,
His words would set their hearts aglow.
For though the world could be unkind,
The poet’s verse would heal the mind.
He spoke of Burns, and all could see
A kindness in adversity,
For men who seemed both rude and rough
Could love, and dream, and feel enough.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Who tilled the soil, whose lives were tough.
Their laughter rang across the fields,
Their pride the only shield it yields.
Yet in the hush of autumn’s end,
They’d listen to the songs that mend.
For Burns, in words both raw and sweet,
Would sing of love and lost defeat.
The men who braved the wind and rain
Could find their comfort in his strain.
He spoke of Burns, and in his eyes
A softer hope would always rise.
For poetry could bridge the gap
Between the coarse and kindly lap.
So raise a glass to those who find
A gentle thought in hearts unkind.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their laughter bold, their edges tough.
Yet in the evening, round the fire,
A gentler spirit would inspire.
With mugs in hand and stories shared,
Their worries eased, their hearts were bared.
For Burns had known the ways of men,
The toil and pain, the loss again.
Yet in his verse, a hope would gleam,
A wish, a song, a distant dream.
He spoke of Burns, and in the night,
The men would find a guiding light.
For poetry could soothe the soul,
And make the broken pieces whole.
So let us raise a toast anew,
To men who feel, and poets too.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their lives were hard, their paths were tough.
With hands of stone and faces lined,
Yet hearts that Burns himself would find.
For in their mirth, their tales, their song,
The poet’s spirit lingered long.
Around the peat fire, voices blend,
Old verses shared, old wounds to mend.
Burns saw the beauty in their strife,
The dignity in humble life.
He honored men of field and glen,
And gave a voice to working men.
He spoke of Burns and in his praise,
The rude and rough found gentler ways.
For poetry, in every land,
Can soften even the hardest hand.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their laughter brayed, their hands were tough.
Yet in their eyes, a secret gleam,
A tenderness, a distant dream.
Burns knew their lives, their loves, their pain,
Their joy and sorrow, loss and gain.
He wrote for men who lived and toiled,
Whose aspirations were not spoiled.
Around the fire, beneath the stars,
They sang his songs and nursed their scars.
For though the world was hard and cold,
A poet’s verse could make them bold.
He spoke of Burns, and in that sound,
A fellowship of souls was found.
For men, though rough, could still be moved
By words that told them they were loved.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their world was raw, their voices gruff.
But through the storm and days of toil,
They loved the land, the rain-soaked soil.
In every jest and every cheer,
A note of longing would appear.
For Burns had given them a tongue,
To tell of love and hope unsung.
They raised a glass to memories lost,
To dreams pursued despite the cost.
And in the firelight’s golden glow,
The poet’s words would softly flow.
He spoke of Burns, and we could see
The soul within adversity.
For men, though rough, could feel the grace
Of poetry in time and place.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Who faced the world so stern and tough.
Yet in their laughter, in their pain,
A gentler note would still remain.
Burns wrote of love, of work, of loss,
Of dreams that vanished like the moss.
And men who heard his verses found
A kindred spirit in the sound.
For poetry can shape the soul,
And make the broken pieces whole.
He spoke of Burns, and in the night,
The roughest men would find the light.
A melody of hope and pride,
A reason not to run or hide.
So let us honor those who knew
The simple words that saw them through.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
With knotted fists and voices gruff.
Their laughter echoed through the moor,
Their lives were simple, hearts were pure.
Yet in the hush of winter’s night,
A softer song would take its flight.
For Burns, he saw beyond the skin,
The dreams and hope that dwelt within.
A ploughman’s heart, a poet’s tongue,
In every verse, his spirit sung.
He spoke of Burns and all could see,
The worth in men of low degree.
For poetry can touch the base,
And bring a tear to weathered face.
So let us raise a toast in turn,
To men like Burns, and all who yearn.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Their voices raw, their hands so tough.
Yet in the warmth of peat and flame,
A different note, a softer name.
Burns wrote of men both poor and proud,
Of laughter loud and sorrows bowed.
He saw the worth in every soul,
The poet’s gift to make them whole.
For in their toil and honest sweat,
A grace the gentry oft forget.
He spoke of Burns, and in the air
A sense of kinship lingered there.
For poetry, through storm and strife,
Can mend the wounds of daily life.
So let us sing as Burns once did,
Of men whose hearts are never hid.

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Whose daily lives were stern and tough.
Yet in their hearts, a gentle song
Of dreams and loves that still belong.
Burns gave them words to name their pain,
To sing of loss and hope again.
The poet’s fire, the worker’s pride,
In every verse, they could confide.
Their hands were scarred, their laughter wide,
Yet Burns’s verses walked beside.
He spoke of Burns, and in that voice,
A nation’s memory would rejoice.
For in the rude, the rough, the plain,
A poet’s soul would still remain.
So raise a glass to Burns’s art—
The bard who knew the common heart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair, beneath the pale and silent moon? 
Night's chill fingers comb my hair, and morning seems to come too soon. 
Yet in this shadowed, hollow space, 
A seed of hope begins to grow— 
For sorrow’s not my sole embrace, 
Nor does despair my limits know. 
Each breath, a trembling promise made, 
Each sigh, a memory that gleams; 
I gather fragments, unafraid, 
And stitch them into waking dreams. 
So let not sorrow claim my heart, 
Nor let regret my soul ensnare; 
I rise, anew, and play my part— 
I will not waste in vain despair.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
For love that never did return? 
The candle’s wax dissolves in air, 
While lonely embers faintly burn. 
Yet hope, like dawn, creeps up the sky, 
Dispelling night with gentle hand— 
I’ll let these bitter sorrows fly, 
And plant new dreams upon this land. 
Despair may call with mournful voice, 
But I shall choose the morning’s light; 
For in the end, I have a choice— 
To turn from darkness, face the bright.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
While seasons circle through the years? 
The petals fall from blooms once fair, 
And water weeps as silent tears. 
Yet in the hush where longing grows, 
A hidden strength begins to rise— 
For every ending, wisdom shows, 
A hope that sorrow can disguise. 
No, I will not yield to night, 
Nor let regret my spirit bind; 
I’ll seek the dawn, pursue the light, 
And leave despairing far behind.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
While shadows gather in my mind? 
The world spins on, but unaware 
Of dreams I leave so far behind. 
Yet in the silence, something stirs— 
A spark that will not be denied; 
For though the night with sorrow blurs, 
A dawn awaits the other side. 
So let me rise from where I fall, 
And cast aside these chains of care; 
I’ll greet the sun and heed its call, 
Refusing to waste in despair.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
Clutching memories worn and cold? 
The world moves on, yet I remain 
Haunted by stories left untold. 
But through the cracks, a gentle light 
Steals softly through the veils of night. 
Hope whispers, urging me to rise, 
To dry my tears and clear my eyes. 
Despair may linger, sharp and deep, 
But I must sow what I can reap. 
Let not my days dissolve in gloom— 
I’ll find the courage to resume.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
With every hour a weight to bear? 
No, let me rise above the gloom, 
And banish shadows from my room. 
For every sorrow, time will heal, 
And lost illusions, new reveal. 
Let hope be kindled in my chest, 
And gentle dreams give me their rest. 
Though darkness lingers, I shall find 
A spark of joy within my mind. 
So, wasting not, I seek the air— 
The promise waiting, bright and fair.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
When morning dew still shines anew? 
Though sorrow calls me unaware, 
I’ll chase the promise in the blue. 
Let not my heart be chained by grief, 
Nor let regret consume my days; 
For in the smallest, greenest leaf, 
I find the hope that softly stays. 
Despair may whisper in the night, 
But I will answer with the dawn; 
And turning sorrow into light, 
I’ll find the strength to carry on.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
As autumn's gold dissolves to rust? 
No, let me find the courage there, 
And lift my spirit from the dust. 
For every fading, dying leaf 
Is proof that beauty comes and goes; 
And though my heart is bruised with grief, 
A deeper understanding grows. 
Despair may darken all the skies, 
But hope is born from what must fade; 
I’ll gather strength as time goes by, 
And rise anew, unafraid.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
Unmoved by dawn’s awakening song? 
No, let me cast aside my care, 
And let my heart to hope belong. 
Though sorrow’s shadow chills my skin, 
A gentle promise softly calls; 
Within the darkness, light begins, 
And from my knees, I will not fall. 
Despair, a visitor, not king— 
I bid you now to take your leave; 
For in my chest, new hopes take wing, 
And teach my soul again to breathe.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
When life’s bright rivers call my name? 
The world is vast, the sky is fair, 
And every day is not the same. 
Let sorrow come and let it go, 
For joy will surely follow soon; 
The seeds of hope I strive to sow, 
Will blossom in another June. 
Despair is but a passing cloud, 
That dims the sun and hides the blue; 
I will not let my spirit bow, 
For hope is old, but always new.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
While seasons slip from gold to gray? 
No, let me breathe the trembling air, 
And find new meaning in the day. 
Though shadows gather at my feet, 
And silence fills the empty hall, 
I will not let my heart retreat, 
Nor let the night forever fall. 
For every ending, hope returns, 
A gentle whisper in the gloom; 
In every sorrow, something learns 
To cradle life and make it bloom.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
While petals fall from summer’s rose? 
The world moves gently, unaware, 
Of silent ache that no one knows. 
Yet in the hush between each sigh, 
A promise lingers, faint and true; 
That even tears which fail to dry, 
Will water seeds of something new. 
Despair may claim a fleeting hour, 
But hope endures the longest night; 
From sorrow’s root, there blooms a flower— 
The fragile blossom of the light.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
While winds of change still stir the air? 
Let not my heart in shadow dwell, 
Nor silence ring my final knell. 
For hope persists through darkest night, 
And dawn returns with gentle might. 
Though bitter tears may stain my face, 
I’ll rise again with quiet grace. 
Despair, you are a passing guest; 
You cannot claim my soul for long. 
In hope and love, I’ll find my rest— 
And learn again to sing my song.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
When time still grants me endless days? 
The world is wide, the sky is fair, 
And hope appears in many ways. 
Despair may knock upon my door, 
But I will choose to let in light; 
For though my heart may ache and sore, 
The morning follows every night. 
So let me rise from sorrow’s bed, 
And step into the waiting sun; 
No longer by regret I’m led— 
A brighter life has just begun.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
As shadows lengthen on the ground? 
Or shall I seek the morning air, 
And let new strength in me be found? 
The night may linger, cold and deep, 
Yet dawn will paint the sky with fire. 
I will not let my spirit sleep, 
But rise and climb a little higher. 
Despair is but a fleeting guest, 
A passing shadow in the night; 
Within my chest, a hope will rest, 
And guide me gently toward the light.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
When love has left its tender mark? 
Let not the ache become my heir, 
Nor let me wander through the dark. 
For every loss, a lesson grows, 
And every tear, a seed of grace; 
Within my soul, the comfort flows, 
And hope returns to take its place. 
Despair may linger for a time, 
A shadow passing through my heart; 
But light will break, and I shall find 
A way for healing to restart.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
When every storm must yield to blue? 
Let sorrow vanish in the air, 
And let my spirit start anew. 
Though bitter winds may shake my frame, 
And tears may fall like summer rain, 
Hope’s gentle spark remains the same, 
And lifts me from my darkest pain. 
Despair, you are a fleeting shade— 
A shadow passing through my door. 
I’ll rise, unbroken and unafraid, 
And choose to live, and love, once more.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
When all the world is still in bloom? 
No, let me breathe the open air, 
And banish sorrow from this room. 
For every winter, spring will come; 
And every tear, a lesson learns. 
Despair, you are a shadowed sum, 
But hope in every corner burns. 
I’ll gather courage, day by day, 
And let the morning heal my heart; 
Despair shall slowly fade away, 
And I will make a brand new start.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
As stars fall silent from the sky? 
No, I will rise beyond the care, 
And let my weary spirit fly. 
Though sorrow’s cloak is soft and deep, 
It cannot keep me bound for long; 
For in my soul, new dreams shall leap, 
And hope will fill my voice with song. 
Despair, you are a passing phase— 
A whisper fading with the night; 
I’ll greet the dawn with open gaze, 
And step once more into the light.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
As lonely hours stretch and wind? 
The echo of an empty chair 
Reminds me what I’ve left behind. 
Yet in the hush, a gentle voice 
Reminds me of the world outside; 
To grieve is human, but I’ll choose 
To let my wounded heart abide. 
Despair, you linger, close and near, 
But I will not become your own; 
For hope persists despite the fear, 
And from my pain, I will have grown.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
When every day brings chance anew? 
The bitter night, the heavy air, 
Will clear as sunlight filters through. 
No chains of sorrow hold me fast— 
I rise, and greet the waking sky; 
My heart will heal, my grief will pass, 
And dreams will find their wings to fly. 
Despair, you are a shadow’s game, 
A fleeting visitor at best; 
I will not waste my heart in shame, 
But claim again my hope and rest.

Shall I wasting in despair, 
When hope still flickers in the gloom? 
Let sorrow’s burden fade to air, 
And light new candles in my room. 
For every shadow, dawn will break, 
And every ache, a lesson teach; 
Despair, you cannot truly take 
The dreams that lie just out of reach. 
So I will rise, though weary grown, 
And find the strength to start anew; 
For I am never quite alone— 
There’s always hope to guide me through.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
The silent dusk now claims your gentle form,  
No laughter echoes where you did employ  
Your brightest smile to warm my heart from storm.  
Your tiny fingers, curled in sleep’s embrace,  
Once grasped my thumb and tethered me to light.  
Now absence haunts the corners of this place,  
And longing paints my dreams with shades of night.  
Yet in the garden, where your footsteps played,  
The flowers bow as if they sense the loss.  
I gather memories, though time may fade,  
And trace your name in dew upon the moss.  
Go gently, child, into that dawn so fair;  
Farewell, my joy, my love beyond compare.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
Beneath pale stars, I whisper soft goodbye.  
Your laughter lingers, fragile as a toy,  
A memory the heart refuses to deny.  
Once, in the golden hush of afternoon,  
Your voice, a song, would brighten every room.  
Now silence presses, heavy and too soon,  
And shadows claim the corners with their gloom.  
Yet love endures, a candle in the dark,  
Its gentle flame undimmed by time or pain.  
Though you must journey where I cannot mark,  
Your spirit’s warmth within me shall remain.  
Farewell, sweet child, my solace and my pride;  
In dreams, in hope, you walk still at my side.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
A star extinguished in the velvet sky.  
What light you brought, no shadow can destroy,  
Nor can the mournful winds your song belie.  
Your laughter, bright as bells upon the breeze,  
Still echoes in the chambers of my mind.  
Though sorrow bends me, brings me to my knees,  
I seek the grace your memory leaves behind.  
Go softly now, beyond the reach of pain,  
Where petals fall and rivers softly gleam.  
I hold you close, though only in refrain,  
A cherished echo in an endless dream.  
Farewell, my joy, my heart’s unbroken thread;  
You live in love, though you are gone and dead.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
The morning breaks, and still I feel your touch.  
A fleeting shadow—absence and alloy—  
Sweet memory woven through my soul as such.  
Your laughter, ringing down the corridor,  
Now lingers softly, like the scent of spring.  
I search the silence for your steps once more,  
Each echo leaves a song my heart must sing.  
O child, my hope, my promise and my pride,  
The days are dimmed and tears fall unrestrained.  
Yet through the sorrow, love will still abide,  
A bond unbroken, ever uncontained.  
Farewell, my child, my right hand, and my light;  
Your spirit guides me through the longest night.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
A gentle soul, now vanished from my sight.  
The laughter gone, the silence now annoy,  
Yet memory clings, a flame against the night.  
Your tiny hand once nestled close to mine,  
A touch that time itself cannot erase.  
Though fate has drawn a solitary line,  
Your spirit lingers, filling empty space.  
Each day I rise, I carry you within,  
Your smile, your hope, the promise of your days.  
Though sorrow’s shadow darkens where you’ve been,  
I find you still in sunlight’s gentle rays.  
Farewell, sweet child, my heart’s enduring song;  
With love, I’ll hold you close my whole life long.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
Your laughter hangs like sunlight in the air.  
No more your steps, no more the games and toy,  
Yet still I find your spirit everywhere.  
The garden blooms where once your fingers played,  
And every petal holds a hint of you.  
Though night descends and colors slowly fade,  
Your memory paints the morning bright and new.  
I mourn the loss, the dreams that cannot be,  
But cherish moments given, not the pain.  
Your love endures—a silent melody  
That fills my soul and gently soothes my brain.  
Farewell, my child, my light, my hope, my song;  
In every heartbeat, you remain lifelong.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
The world feels hollow with your absence here.  
No more your laughter, no more shared employ,  
Just memories I hold forever dear.  
Your gentle touch, your gaze, your hopeful eyes,  
Live on within the chambers of my soul.  
Though grief remains, and silent sorrow cries,  
Your love persists and keeps my spirit whole.  
The night grows long, yet dawn will surely break,  
And I will rise, remembering your grace.  
For every tear, a thousand smiles awake,  
And in my dreams, again I see your face.  
Farewell, beloved, though we are apart;  
You dwell forever, child, within my heart.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
A gentle spirit, lost before its time.  
Your laughter once did every care destroy,  
And made my days a sweeter, softer rhyme.  
Though now you sleep where no dawn breaks anew,  
And silence falls where once your feet would run,  
I keep your memory, tender and true,  
A golden thread that binds me to the sun.  
O child, whose love could banish darkest night,  
Whose eyes could kindle hope when all seemed lost,  
Though I must grieve, I cherish every light,  
Each moment gifted, precious beyond cost.  
Farewell, my joy, my heart’s enduring song;  
Your spirit in my soul will ever long.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
The morning’s hush enfolds your gentle name.  
The toys lie still, bereft of all employ,  
Yet love within me burns a constant flame.  
Your laughter’s echo, ringing down the hall,  
Still stirs the dust motes dancing in the light.  
Though shadows stretch and heavy teardrops fall,  
I hold you close, unseen, throughout the night.  
O precious child, whose touch the world redeemed,  
Your absence leaves a sorrow deep and wide.  
Yet hope endures, and as I once had dreamed,  
Your spirit walks forever by my side.  
Farewell, sweet joy, my hand, my heart, my grace;  
In every dawn, your memory I’ll embrace.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
The golden dawn now finds my heart alone.  
Where once your laughter rose without alloy,  
Now echoes fill a house no longer home.  
Your tiny hand, your gaze so full of trust,  
Remain as footprints pressed upon my soul.  
Though time may gather memories to dust,  
Your light endures and keeps my spirit whole.  
In silent rooms, your whispered dreams remain,  
Soft as the breath of petals on the breeze.  
Though pain persists, and longing leaves its stain,  
Love’s gentle grace still offers me some ease.  
Farewell, my joy, my cherished, dearest child;  
In every beat, your spirit reconciled.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
The sun dips low, the day resigns its gold.  
Once laughter bright, now silence must employ  
Its gentle hush where once your hand I’d hold.  
Yet in the quiet, memories arise—  
Your voice, your smile, your ever-trusting gaze.  
Though tears may fall, and longing fill my eyes,  
Your love endures through all my fleeting days.  
O gentle child, so cherished and so fair,  
Your spirit weaves through every hopeful dream.  
Though parted now, I feel you everywhere—  
In morning’s light, in every starlit gleam.  
Farewell, sweet joy, my heart’s unbroken thread;  
Through all of life, by love I shall be led.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
A chapter closed, though love remains unspent.  
The laughter lost, the quiet now employs  
A solemn hush where all my tears are sent.  
Your tiny feet no longer cross the floor,  
Yet echoes of your presence fill the air.  
Though time may pass and wounds may slowly heal,  
The bond we share will linger always there.  
O gentle child, so precious and so dear,  
Your light endures within my broken heart.  
Though I must grieve and wipe away each tear,  
In dreams, we never truly are apart.  
Farewell, my joy, my hope, my guiding star;  
You walk beside me, loved from near and far.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
A silent cradle rocks in empty air.  
The laughter gone, the shadows now destroy  
The golden dreams I wove with loving care.  
Yet in the dusk, your memory remains,  
A gentle whisper drifting through the gloom.  
Though time may try to ease my aching pains,  
Your presence softly lingers in the room.  
O precious child, whose smile could light the day,  
Your spirit soars beyond my earthbound sight.  
Though parted now, I’ll walk the winding way,  
And keep your love as beacon through the night.  
Farewell, sweet joy, my heart’s enduring part;  
You live forever nestled in my heart.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
A gentle hush descends upon the room.  
The toys abandoned, silent of employ,  
Now rest beneath the weight of quiet gloom.  
Yet in the dusk, your laughter softly plays,  
A melody that time cannot erase.  
Though sorrow weaves its dark and tangled maze,  
I find your light in every shadowed space.  
O cherished soul, whose love was pure and bright,  
Though you depart, your memory holds me near.  
Your spirit, like a star, still burns at night,  
Dispelling all the darkness born of fear.  
Farewell, my joy, my comfort and my guide;  
Your love, eternal, walks close by my side.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
The gentle dusk enfolds the world in grey.  
Your laughter gone, the silence must employ  
Its patient hand to guide me through the day.  
Yet in the garden, petals softly fall,  
A quiet echo of your fleeting years.  
Though sorrow’s tide may rise and shadows call,  
Your memory shines bright despite my tears.  
O precious child, your spirit’s gentle light  
Still warms my heart, though distance lies between.  
In every star that twinkles in the night,  
I find your love, unbroken and serene.  
Farewell, my joy, my hope, my guiding star;  
You live within me, never truly far.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
Upon the quiet cradle, dust now lies.  
No more your laughter can my fears destroy,  
No more your gaze can brighten weary eyes.  
Yet in the silent corners of my mind,  
Your memory lingers, steadfast and profound.  
Though time moves on and leaves us both behind,  
Our love persists, a song without a sound.  
O gentle child, whose presence graced my days,  
Your spirit walks beside me, soft and true.  
Though sorrow weaves its web through memory’s haze,  
I carry all my hopes and dreams of you.  
Farewell, sweet joy, my heart’s enduring flame;  
In every breath, I softly speak your name.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
The evening hush enfolds the empty room.  
No more your laughter does my heart employ,  
No more your smile dispels the creeping gloom.  
Yet in the quiet, memories arise—  
A gentle touch, a voice so pure and bright.  
Though tears may fall, and longing fill my eyes,  
Your spirit lingers, guiding me through night.  
O precious soul, your love forever near,  
A beacon shining through the darkest storm.  
Though I must grieve, I hold your memory dear,  
A cherished presence, comforting and warm.  
Farewell, my joy, my hope, my sweetest part;  
You dwell forever deep within my heart.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
A gentle echo ripples through the years.  
The moments lost, no sorrow can destroy,  
Nor can the tide of time erase my tears.  
Your laughter, golden as the morning sun,  
Still lights the corners of my aching soul.  
Though you have gone where journeys are begun,  
Your memory lingers, making broken whole.  
O dearest child, whose love could not be bound,  
By fate’s design, I must release your hand.  
Yet in the silence, hope and peace are found,  
As love endures, unshaken, as I planned.  
Farewell, my joy, my solace and my pride;  
In dreams and memory, you walk beside.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
A hush falls softly on your empty bed.  
The laughter stilled, no more the bright employ  
Of tiny hands, the gentle words unsaid.  
Yet in my heart, a garden blooms anew,  
Each flower watered by a tear or smile.  
Though grief is sharp, I carry close to you  
A love that time nor distance could defile.  
Go gently, child, into the silent dawn,  
Beyond my reach, yet never far away.  
For every night that falls, a hope is drawn—  
We’ll meet again at close of final day.  
Farewell, my joy, my blessing, and my song;  
Your spirit in my soul will ever long.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
A gentle shadow passes through the room.  
The echoes of your laughter now employ  
A softer light to chase away the gloom.  
Though tears may fall, and silence fills the space,  
Your memory lingers, warm and ever near.  
Each thought of you a gentle, sweet embrace,  
A whispered comfort through each longing tear.  
The days will pass, the seasons turn and bend,  
Yet love remains, unbroken by the years.  
Though we are parted, this is not the end—  
Your spirit lives in joy and not in fears.  
Farewell, my child, my right hand, and my heart;  
Though worlds divide, we’re never truly apart.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;  
In twilight’s hush, your laughter fades away.  
No more the light your gentle hands employ,  
Nor footsteps echo softly in their play.  
Yet in the stillness, memories remain,  
A comfort clinging close in sorrow’s arms.  
Though tears may fall and grief becomes my chain,  
Your love endures, a balm against all harms.  
O precious child, whose presence graced my days,  
Your spirit lingers, shining ever bright.  
Though parted now, my heart with longing stays,
